item.title: Introduction
item.description: Introduction Those are the Topics that you are going to work on during this Training Introduction ... In this Training you will learn how to install IBM CloudPak for AIOps and how to configure some basic functionnalities. The idea is to provide you with an optimised way to learn CP4WAIOPS. You will learn about the following topics: Installing AI Manager from scratch Integrate AI Manager with OpenLDAP for user management Integrate AI Manager with ELK for Log Anomalies Define and train AI Models for Log Anomaly Detectiom Metric Anomaly Detection Event Grouping Similar Incidents Change Risk Create Policies for Story creation and Runbook assignment Integrate AI Manager with Ansible Tower and create Runbooks in AI Manager Create a RobotShop Application Topology Integrate AI Manager with Slack In the end you will have a fully functioning demo environment.

item.title: Basic Architecture
item.description: Basic Architecture The environement (Kubernetes, Applications, …) create logs that are being fed into a Log Management Tool (ELK in this case). External Systems generate Alerts and send them into the AI Manager for Event Grouping. At the same time AI Manager ingests the raw logs coming from the Log Management Tool (ELK) and looks for anomalies in the stream based on the trained model. It also ingests Metric Data and looks for anomalies If it finds an anomaly (logs and/or metrics) it forwards it to the Event Grouping as well.

item.title: Training Architecture
item.description: Optimized Training Architecture For the this specific Demo environment: ELK is installed for you to kearn how to integrate it For Log Anomaly simulation we’ll beusing pre-canned logs for the anomaly detection (inception) For Metrics, we’ll be using pre-canned metric data for training and for the anomaly detection (inception) The Events will be created from pre-canned content that is injected into AI Manager There are also pre-canned ServiceNow Incidents as we don‚Äôt do the live integration with SNOW for this training The Webpages that are reachable from the Events are static and hosted on my GitHub The same goes for ServiceNow Incident pages if you don‚Äôt integrate with live SNOW

item.title: Installing the Operator
item.description: Installing the Operator In this chapter you will prepare your Cluster for the installation of AI Manager Prepare your PC or Mac to run commands against your cluster Create the basic resources (Namespace) Create the IBM Operator Catalog Install the CP4WAIOPS Operator

item.title: Preparing to run commands
item.description: Preparing to run commands The official documentation can be found here. Befor continuing, you have to connect to your OpenShift Cluster. Open your Openshift Web Console Select Copy Login Command Copy the oc login .. string Open your terminal Paste the oc login .. command from above Clone the GitHub Repository into your directory of choice git clone https://github.com/niklaushirt/cp4waiops-deployer.git Go to the deployer directory cd cp4waiops-deployer Now you’re good to start with the installation.

item.title: Preparing Installation
item.description: Preparing Installation Create the namespace (project) üí° This creates the Namespace in which you will install AI Manager Create a namespace called cp4waiops, by running the following command: oc create namespace cp4waiops Create the OperatorGroup üí° This creates the OperatorGroup needed for the Operator to deploy into the cp4waiops Namespace Create the Operator group by running the following command: cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1 kind: OperatorGroup metadata: name: cp4waiops-operator-group namespace: cp4waiops spec: targetNamespaces: - cp4waiops EOF Create the entitlement key pull secret üí° This creates the Secret with your IBM Entitlement that will allow the images to be pulled from the IBM Container Registry

item.title: Install Catalog
item.description: Installing the Catalog üí° This creates the CatalogSource that provides the available IBM Operators (not just CP4WAIOPS). You can go to Operators/OperatorHub in your Openshift Web Console to check out the available Operators Run the following command to create the CatalogSource. cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1alpha1 kind: CatalogSource metadata: name: ibm-operator-catalog namespace: openshift-marketplace spec: displayName: ibm-operator-catalog publisher: IBM Content sourceType: grpc image: icr.io/cpopen/ibm-operator-catalog:latest EOF Update the CatalogSource to always use the current image digest by running the following commands:

item.title: Install Operator
item.description: Installing the Operator üí° This creates the Operator instance that will be looking for an Installation definition and start the installation if it exists (you’ll create this in one of the next steps). Run the following command: cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: operators.coreos.com/v1alpha1 kind: Subscription metadata: name: ibm-aiops-orchestrator namespace: cp4waiops spec: channel: v3.5 installPlanApproval: Automatic name: ibm-aiops-orchestrator source: ibm-operator-catalog sourceNamespace: openshift-marketplace EOF

item.title: Check Installation
item.description: Check Operator is ready Verify that the Operator is running. Either run the following: oc get csv -n cp4waiops And you should see TODO entries with Succeeded state NAME DISPLAY VERSION REPLACES PHASE ibm-aiops-orchestrator.v3.5.1 IBM Cloud Pak for Watson AIOps AI Manager 3.5.1 Succeeded ibm-automation-core.v1.3.11 IBM Automation Foundation Core 1.3.11 ibm-automation-core.v1.3.10 Succeeded ibm-automation-elastic.v1.3.10 IBM Elastic 1.3.10 ibm-automation-elastic.v1.3.9 Succeeded ibm-automation-eventprocessing.v1.3.11 IBM Automation Foundation Event Processing 1.3.11 ibm-automation-eventprocessing.v1.3.10 Succeeded ibm-automation-flink.v1.3.10 IBM Automation Foundation Flink 1.

item.title: Install AI Manager
item.description: Creating the AI Manager Instance Now it’s time to create the AI Manager instance üí° This creates the Installation instance that the Operator will pick up and start the installation. Run the following command to create an instance of AI Manager. cat << EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: orchestrator.aiops.ibm.com/v1alpha1 kind: Installation metadata: name: ibm-cp-watson-aiops namespace: cp4waiops spec: imagePullSecret: ibm-entitlement-key license: accept: true pakModules: - name: aiopsFoundation enabled: true - name: applicationManager enabled: true - name: aiManager enabled: true - name: connection enabled: false size: small storageClass: ibmc-file-gold-gid storageClassLargeBlock: ibmc-block-gold EOF üí° This takes some time depending on what region of ROKS you have chosen.

item.title: Check Installation
item.description: Check AI Manager is ready üí° This takes some time depending on what region of ROKS you have chosen. ‚ùó Wait up to 45 minutes for the installation to complete. The next step explains how to follow the installation progress. Check with the Command Line Run the following: while :; do clear; echo "Checking..."; echo "Exit with Ctrl-C"; oc get po -n cp4waiops | grep -v Completed | grep -v Error |grep "0/"; oc get po -n cp4waiops | grep -v Completed | grep -v Error |grep -v "0/" |wc -l| tr -d ' '; oc get po -n cp4waiops | grep -v Completed | grep -v Error |grep "0/" |wc -l| tr -d ' '; sleep 2; done This will list the Pods that are not Ready yet.

item.title: Training Resources
item.description: Installing Training resources This will install resources that you will need for the configuration of AI Manager in the next chapter. Those are assets that typically already exist at a customer: OpenLDAP AWX (Open Source Ansible Tower) with preloaded Playbooks RobotShop Demo App Demo Service Account This will also load training data for: Log Anomalies You will integrate with your live ELK instance but you probably don’t have 2-3 days to wait for ELK to collect enough logs.

item.title: Installing Training Resources
item.description: Installing Training resources üí° This creates a Job in the default Namespace that will create and load all the stuff that you need for the next chapter. Run the following code to start the creation of the Training Resources. cat << EOF | oc apply -f - kind: ClusterRoleBinding apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1 metadata: name: installer-default-default roleRef: apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io kind: ClusterRole name: cluster-admin subjects: - kind: ServiceAccount name: default namespace: default --- apiVersion: batch/v1 kind: Job metadata: name: waiops-easy-install-aimanager-practicum namespace: default spec: serviceAccountName: installer-default-default template: spec: containers: - name: install image: niklaushirt/cp4waiops-tools:1.

item.title: Check Installation
item.description: Check Training Resources are ready üí° This takes some time depending on what region of ROKS you have chosen. ‚ùó Wait up to 15-20 minutes for the installation to complete. The next step explains how to follow the installation progress. You can follow along the process by running: ./tools/11_fzth/stream_remote_logs.sh Or through the OpensHift Web Console: Select default Namespace Select Pods Click on the waiops-easy-install-aimanager-practicum-... Pod Select Logs üöÄ And when done you should get the following with failed=0.

item.title: Get the information
item.description: Get the configuration information Run the following command to get a list of all the information that you will need for the configuration of AI Manager in this chapter. ./tools/11_fzth/get_configuration_info.sh This will provide you with all the information and details that you need to configure AI Manager in this chapter. üí° ‚ö†Ô∏è You can also save the information to a file to keep it handy ./tools/11_fzth/get_configuration_info.sh > MY_CONFIGURATION.txt

item.title: First Login
item.description: Login to AI Manager In your OpenShift Console click on the Applications Menu Select CP4WAIOps Demo UI Login with token P4ssw0rd! Copy the Admin Password Open AI Manager Select IBM provided credentials Login with admin user and the password you copied in the step above Welcome to AI Manager

item.title: Initialize ELK
item.description: Initialize ELK In your OpenShift Console click on the Applications Menu Select Logging Click Allow selected permissions Input app* for the index pattern Click Next Step Select @timestamp for time filter Click Create Index Pattern Click on Discover ELK is now configured. Verify that you have Logs coming in.

item.title: Configure LDAP
item.description: Configure LDAP integration Create LDAP provider In the AI Manager “Hamburger” Menu select Access Control In the top right Click Identity provider configuration You might have to re-login with your admin user In the top right Click New Connection Select LDAP from the dropdown Click Next üîé Get the data from your configuration info - section 2.1 Configure LDAP ./tools/11_fzth/get_configuration_info.sh Fill out the first section of fields: Connection name: LDAP Server type: Custom Base DN: dc=ibm,dc=com Bind DN: cn=admin,dc=ibm,dc=com Bind DN password: P4ssw0rd!

item.title: Configure ELK
item.description: Configure ELK In the AI Manager “Hamburger” Menu select Define/Data and tool connections Click Add connection Under ELK, click on Add connection Click Connect Name it ELK üîé Get the data from your configuration info - section 2.2 Configure ELK ./tools/11_fzth/get_configuration_info.sh Fill out the fields on the first page: ELK service URL: from script Kibana URL: from script Authentication type: Token Token: from script Mapping: { "codec": "elk", "message_field": "message", "log_entity_types": "kubernete s.

item.title: Configure Runbooks
item.description: Configure Runbooks Create Ansible Tower Connection In the AI Manager “Hamburger” Menu select Define/Data and tool connections Click Add connection Under Ansible Automation Controller, click on Add connection Click Connect üîé Get the data from your configuration info - section 2.3 Configure Runbooks - Ansible Automation Controller ./tools/11_fzth/get_configuration_info.sh Fill out the fields: URL for REST API: from script Authentication type: User ID/Password User: admin Password: from script Click Done

item.title: Configure Policies
item.description: Configure Policies Enable Story creation Policy In the AI Manager “Hamburger” Menu select Operate/Automations Select tab Policies Click on the Tag dropdown Select Stories and Runbooks Turn on Policy Default story creation policy for all alerts Create Runbook Assignment Policy Click on Create Policy Click on Assign a runbook to alerts Name it RobotShop Mitigate MySQL Problem Scroll down to Condition sets Click in field Property Type name Select resource / name

item.title: Configure Applications
item.description: Create Kubernetes Observer In the AI Manager “Hamburger” Menu select Define/Data and tool connections Click Add connection Under Kubernetes, click on Add connection Click Connect üîé Get the data from your configuration info - section 2.5 Configure Applications - RobotShop Kubernetes Observer ./tools/11_fzth/get_configuration_info.sh Fill out the first section of fields (Add connection): Name: RobotShop Data center: robot-shop Click Next Fill out the first section of fields (Set advanced options):

item.title: Configure Certificates
item.description: Create valid Ingress Certificates Patch NetworkPolicy Run the following command to patch the NetworkPolicy export WAIOPS_NAMESPACE=$(oc get po -A|grep aiops-orchestrator-controller |awk '{print$1}') cat <<EOF | oc apply -f - apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1 kind: NetworkPolicy metadata: name: allow-all-egress-and-ingress annotations: argocd.argoproj.io/sync-wave: "3" namespace: $WAIOPS_NAMESPACE spec: egress: - {} ingress: - {} podSelector: {} policyTypes: - Egress - Ingress EOF Run the following command to patch AutomationUIConfig Certificates export WAIOPS_NAMESPACE=$(oc get po -A|grep aiops-orchestrator-controller |awk '{print$1}') oc project $WAIOPS_NAMESPACE NAMESPACE=$WAIOPS_NAMESPACE AUTO_UI_INSTANCE=$(oc get AutomationUIConfig -n $NAMESPACE --no-headers -o custom-columns=":metadata.

item.title: Create Test Incident
item.description: Create Test Incident In your OpenShift Console click on the Applications Menu Select CP4WAIOps Demo UI Login with token P4ssw0rd! Click on Create Incident Memory Leak Wait for pop-up to go away and the Demo UI going back to the homepage

item.title: Examine the Incident
item.description: Examine the Incident In the AI Manager “Hamburger” Menu select Operate/Stories and Alerts Click on Alerts You should see some Alerts coming in Click on Stories You should see some Stories Click on the first Story in the list (it should be P2 or P1 but the name can differ) You should see some Stories You should see the detail of the Story, with the Probable Cause, the Runbooks and the Similar Incidents

item.title: Clear the Incident
item.description: Clear the Incident Go back to the Demo UI Click on Clear Stories and Events Wait for pop-up to go away and the Demo UI going back to the homepage The Alerts will be Closed and the Stories Resolved You will have to wait for about 10 minutes for them to disappear (you can recreate the incident earlier, which will just re-open the existing Stories )

item.title: Slack Setup
item.description: Initial Slack Setup For the system to work you need to setup your own secure gateway and slack workspace. It is suggested that you do this within the public slack so that you can invite the customer to the experience as well. It also makes it easier for is to release this image to Business partners You will need to create your own workspace to connect to your instance of CP4WAOps.

item.title: Create Workspace
item.description: Create your Slack Workspace Create a Slack workspace by going to https://slack.com/get-started#/createnew and logging in with an email which is not your IBM email. Your IBM email is part of the IBM Slack enterprise account and you will not be able to create an independent Slack workspace outside if the IBM slack service. After authentication, you will see the following screen: Click Create a Workspace -> Name your Slack workspace

item.title: Create Your App
item.description: Create Your Slack App Create a Slack app, by going to https://api.slack.com/apps and clicking Create New App. Select From an app manifest Select the appropriate workspace that you have created before and click Next Copy and paste the content of this file slack-app-manifest.yaml. Adapt the Name and Display Name to your likings üí° Don’t bother with the URLs just yet, we will adapt them as needed. Click Next Click Create

item.title: Create Your Channels
item.description: Create Your Slack Channels In Slack add a two new channels: cp4waiops-stories cp4waiops-change-risk üí° You can name the whatever you want. Right click on each channel and select Copy Link This should get you something like this https://xxxx.slack.com/archives/C021QOY16BW The last part of the URL is the channel ID (i.e. C021QOY16BW). üí° Jot them down for both channels Under Apps click Browse Apps Select the App you just have created

item.title: Integrate
item.description: Integrate Your Slack App In the Slack App: In the Basic Information menu get the Signing Secret (not the Client Secret!) and jot it down In the OAuth & Permissions get the Bot User OAuth Token (not the User OAuth Token!) and jot it down In AI Manager: Go to Data and tool connections Under Slack select Add integration Name it “Slack” Paste the Signing Secret from above Paste the Bot User OAuth Token from above

item.title: Get the Integration URL
item.description: Get the Integration URL (Public Cloud (ROKS, …)) Create the Integration URL In AI Manager: Go to Data and tool connections Under Slack click on 1 integration Copy out the URL This is the URL you will be using for step 6.

item.title: Configure
item.description: Create Slack App Communications Return to the browser tab for the Slack app. Event Subscriptions Select Event Subscriptions. In the Enable Events section, click the slider to enable events. For the Request URL field use the Request URL from step 5. e.g: https://<my-url>/aiops/aimanager/instances/xxxxx/api/slack/events After pasting the value in the field, a Verified message should display. If you get an error please check that you have followed this Verify that on the Subscribe to bot events section you got:
